 Technical Annex Page 1 of 27 A. BACKGROUND General 1. Bosnia and ]Herzegovina (BH) has a total area of 51,500 km2. As a consequence of the Dayton agreement the country is administratively divided into two parts: the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (the Federation), which is mainly inhabited by the Muslim and Croat ethnic communities (approximately 26,500 kn2), and Republika Srpska (RS), with mainly Serb communities (approximately 25,000 ki2). The population before the war was 4.4 million people. In 1996, it was estimated that over one million people lived abroad and another 1.5 million were refugees within the boundaries of BH. Rural areas in many parts of the country were totally abandoned by its former inhabitants. 2. Before the war, forestry and wood based industries were an important part of the economy, accounting for more than 10 percent of GSP1. Forestry alone accounted for about two percent of GSP, with important and well managed forest resources. In 1990 the forest and the forest industry sector employed 36,000 persons and accounted for an export value of US$250 million. The forest industries were well developed and exported high quality products. Due to the war, the extraction of wood from the forests and the production of the wood industry were much reduced. It is estimated that, for the period 1992-95, the total utilization of installed capacity was only between 10 and 15 percent of pre-war levels. Forest Resources and Management 3. Forest Resources. The forest resources of Bosnia are amongst the highest in Europe, in terms of extent and stock, when related to the size of the country. Forest land covers about 2.6 million ha, or about 50 percent of the total BH land area, of which about 2.1 million ha are actually covered with forests -- including 1.3 millon ha of high forests and 0.8 million ha of low forests -- the balance being composed of bare lands2 . About 65 percent of the standing stock of Bosnian forests are broadleaves, mainly beech and oak species, and 35 percent conifers, including fir, spruce, and pine species. About 45 percent of high forests stands are mixed broadleaves and conifers while pure broadleaves and conifers represent 40 percent and 15 percent of these stands respectively; low forests stands are composed of broadleaves only, either in mixed stands (55%) or pure stands of beech or oak. The State owns 81 percent of forest land and private holdings constitute 19 percent. The total growing stock on BH State land amounted to 359 million m3 (i.e., 93% of the total) or 215 m3/ha of forested land in 1990. Corresponding figures for the private forests were 27 million rn3 (i.e., 7% of the total) and 62 ni3/ha respectively. The present distribution of forest resources, in terms of areas and standing stock is about 55 percent for the Federation and 45 percent for RS. Corresponding figures are shown in Table 1 below. 4. Actual removal of wood from Bosnian State forests before the war, when compared with the Annual Allowable Cut (AAC) and estimated yield, indicates a conservative harvesting policy. Between 1981 and 1990, the estimated annual current increment of the standing stock of Bosnian State forests was 9.1 million rn3. During the same period, the AAC for these forests -- which is the sum of the individual AACs adopted under the forest management plans (FMPs) developed for each State Forest Enterprise (SFE) -- averaged about 6.8 million ni3. After adjustment for illegal cutting of logs and fuel wood (the latter mainly took place in low forests), the total harvesting in BH is likely to have been about 2 million rn3 per year during the war or about 20 percent of the estimated current increment of the standing stock and 30 percent of the AAC. Since adequate control over harvesting has not yet been re-established, there are increasing accounts of illegal harvesting and log smuggling. Since normal accessibility to forests has not yet been restored, overharvesting is increasingly likely to take place in accessible areas. 7. Forest Biodiversity. Bosnia's forests have a rich biological diversity, including an estimated 400 rare species of flora and over 200 rare species of fauna. The government organization for wildlife protection3 is finishing the preparation of the list of flora species which are either threatened or endangered; around 10 species are considered endangered so far. The government intends to start with the preparation of a similar list for fauna species. The major threatened species are predatory birds (nine of them are endangered) and aquatic birds (five are considered endangered). Besides the aforementioned nine birds living in terrestrial ecosystems, there are 153 more singing birds and birds useful for forestry and agriculture, as well as 66 aquatic birds. During the war, a large population of bears left the country for forests in Slovenia and Croatia. Some are coming back, but the risk of crossing mined areas in high. All the aforementioned birds and a large number of small mammals are going to be included in the fauna list. 8. Currently there is no Environmental Law, but there are three major laws which contain enviromnental provisions: (i) the Natural Heritage Law (issued in 1985, concerning the establishment and management of protected areas); (ii) the Water Resources Law; and (iii) the Forest Law (issued in 1978, which basically defines rules for production forestry but also includes aspects on forest protection). New laws on land use, environmental protection and forest are currently being drafted. The new law on environmental protection will draw together and strengthen the environmental provisions contained in the existing sectoral laws. Under this new law, a series of regulations on water, air and natural resources management will be promulgated, including emission and environmental quality standards for the control of water and air pollution, and the establishment of the environmental inspection system. Based on the experience in the other former Yugoslav republics, it is expected that environmental legislation will be formulated to be in compliance with the European Union (EU) and agreed international conventions. 9. In BH there are 31 protected areas,4 most of which are in RS, including the two national parks of BH: the National Park of Sutjeska, with an area of 17,250 ha, including one of the last remnant of the primary forest of Europe (the Perucica forest covering some 1,400 ha); and the National Park of Kozara, with an area of 3,375 ha, which has been mainly established to protect historical heritage. The Federation has only three small virgin/primary forests (total area of 375 ha) and three small reserves (420 ha). About one percent of the territory of BH is protected which is lower than international norms. In 1980, it was proposed that four percent of the territory of BH be set aside as protected areas. In the same year, an environmental strategy was developed to increase this to 16 percent by the year 2000. Between 1980 and the beginning of the war, a number of studies were carried out and some new areas were identified for conservation action as areas of special value for their ecological diversity, sites that are environmentally fragile, and places of scenic interest with ecotourism potential. Some of these areas have been studied as potential new national parks, including the mountains of Treskavica and Igman Bjelasnica close to Sarajevo, and the mountains of Preni, Cursnica and Cabulja located near the border of Bosnia with Herzegovina. Due to the war and subsequent division of the Republic into two entities, the four percent objective was not reached nor is it likely that the 16 percent strategy will be implemented by the year 2,000. 3 Institute for Protection of Cultural, Historical and Natural Heritage of BH (IPCHNH). There is a long tradition of sustainable management of forests in Bosnia -- originally based on principles introduced by the Austrians during the 1890s -- which is now regulated by law. The overall Government policy is to: (i) improve the high forests, by increasing density and growing stock and making a better utilization of site conditions; (ii) convert gradually coppice and shrub in low forests into more productive forests where economically and environmentally acceptable; and (iii) convert productive bare lands into forests. 11. Forest management in Bosnia is mainly based on selective felling systems that aim to achieve a full spectrum of ages in each forest stand. In such systems, harvesting takes place at regular intervals (about every 10th year) so that the same amount, quality and species distribution will be available at the following harvesting intervals. At present the following four systems guide the management of the forests: (i) selective cutting, implying removal of damaged and dead trees and also oversized trees (more than 80 cm in diameter); (ii) combined selective cutting and group selection cutting (clearfelling of small areas (0.3-0.5 ha) are also allowed); (iii) group selection cutting in pure stands of either broadleaves or conifers in combination with clearfelling of areas up to 2.0 ha; and (iv) clearfelling of degraded high forests and coppice forests for planting of areas up to 20 ha mainly with conifers. 12. According to the Forest Law, forest regeneration (or "simple regeneration") is mandatory; for each gross cubic meter felled, 14 rn2 of forests has to be regenerated. Under the above first three systems -- which are in force over about 95 percent of the area of State forests -- forest regeneration used to be predominantly and successfully natural, which ensures ecosystems sustainability and biodiversity conservation. Reforestation of degraded high forests and coppice, mainly with conifers, was also an important element of forest management before the war. Afforestation of bare lands (also called "extended regeneration"), however, was not achieved as planned, mainly because of lack of financing which was supposed to come from the wood processing industries and local and central authorities. Between 1981-90, an average of 13,400 ha per annum was planted for both reforestation and afforestation. Around 42 million seedlings were produced annually -- in 10 major nurseries covering a total area of about 300 ha -- from seeds of right provenances and proven good quality collected from trees and high quality seed stands registered and tested from a genetic point of view. 13. Forests in BH are managed according to FMPs developed for each SFE with a duration of 10-20 years. Before the war, FMPs were developed by specialized forest management planning units (see para. 17) located in Sarajevo and Banja Luka, usually over an 18-month period of combined field and desk work. FMPs had to be approved first by the communes before final approval at the ministerial level. FMPs aim for sustainable management and are based on the collection of detailed data on the status of the forests and on modem forest management principles. The AAC set in these FMPs is lower than the potential biological increment because of the above mentioned policy to increase the standing stock and the increasing protective functions assigned to the forests. Based on the FMPs, SFEs prepare annual plans which have to be approved at the ministerial level. The annual plans contain details of compartments to be cut or otherwise treated, volumes to be removed (distributed on assortments), areas to be planted, roads to be constructed and maintained, and budgets. Topographical maps in scales 1:10,000, 1:25,000 and 1:50,000, and forestry treatment maps are available for planning purposes. 14. The war severely affected forest management, in varying ways. A significant amount of forests are now inaccessible because of minefields -- from an estimated 15 percent - 20 percent of the total area in the Federation to 20 percent - 25 percent in RS. The AAC will have to be reduced accordingly until these mines are cleared. Based on the preliminary results from an ongoing assessment of Bosnian forest cover

In most cases, destruction has affected numerous but small areas of forests, either as a direct consequence of the war through artillery and grenades (both in the form of destroyed trees and trees with shrapnel damage), or as an indirect consequence through uncontrolled overexploitation of accessible forests for fuelwood. 15. Another major consequence of the war on forests and forest management is an outbreak of insect attacks mainly on coniferous forests. Populations of bark beetles -- mostly the bark borer (Ips typographus) - have exploded because of two main reasons: first, direct war damage to spruce and fir trees made them more susceptible to insect attacks; second, sanitary fellings -- and other management practices that normally keep insect attacks under control - were discontmued during the war and have not yet resumed. Controlling this outbreak is urgent because bark beetles, usually secondary pests (i.e., attacking trees already weakened by another pest or another cause), are becoming primary pests (i.e., attacking healthy trees). Controlling this outbreak also calls for methods other than usual management practices, since the sources of infestation are concentrated in areas with poor accessibility because of mines or an inadequate forest road network. 16. During the war, all reforestation and afforestation efforts came to a halt. The production of seedlings was discontinued, and the units for seed collection and processing in operation before the war were destroyed. There is an urgent need to rehabilitate the nursery capacity, for the forestry reconstruction program, and to make funding available for immediate reforestation needs in sensitive areas affected by war damage, where adequate financing mechanisms for reforestation and afforestation are not yet in place. In the Bosniac part of the Federation, these mechanisms do not exist; in the Herzegovinian part of the Federation a tax of 0.07 percent on the profit from all commercial companies should be devoted to afforestation purposes, but is not yet operational; in RS, similar mechanisms are in place and considered operational. 17. The development of FMPs has been discontinued since the beginning of the war and has not yet resumed. The specialized forest management planning units in Sarajevo and Banja Luka are not able to resume their activity since the former has been disbanded and the latter has lost all its equipment. As a result, FMPs have now expired in about two third of the SFEs. In addition, a revision of some valid FMPs is necessary due to the impact of the war in terms of changed boundaries of the SFEs close to the confrontation line, and direct or indirect damage to the forests. The cumulative number of SFEs with expired FMPs, FMPs to expire up to the end of 1998, and FMPs which need revision due to the war, may amount to about 75 percent of the total. There is an urgent need to resume the preparation of FMPs. The management planning units have to be operational again and exchange their information base, since the area they used to cover is different from what they are covering now in the Federation and in RS. 18. Harvesting Practices. Logging practices are fairly well developed in Bosnia. Chainsaws are used for felling and bucking. Medium sized skidding tractors with articulated steering dominate off-road transport, but farm tractors are also used when the terrain conditions permit. Horses are still used in both the Federation and RS and also oxen in RS, especially for the sensitive operations such as the "one tree selective cuttings". Surprisingly there seem to be very few cable logging systems in operation. The authorities estimate that only five percent of the harvested volume is transported with some kind of cable logging system. Average off-road transport distance is reported to be around 650 m going up to a maximum of 2,000 m in areas with low road density. Chainsaws and tractors are most often owned by the SFEs, but there is a tendency for private entrepreneurs and buyers of the wood to become increasingly involved. The road transport operations are performed with trucks of varying type and standard. Trucks

Most of the wood harvesting and transport equipment was destroyed during the war. The share of equipment destroyed is more significant in the Federation than in RS. Based on reports from the SFEs, only the following share of pre-war equipment still remains (% in the Federation - % in RS): chainsaws (10%-26%); skidders (17%/o-31%); andtrucks (280/o-50%). In addition, most ofthe equipment remaining in SFEs is composed of old machinery and is performing poorly because of lack of maintenance during the war. Since the end of the war, wood harvesting is recovering thanks to international assistance that has provided SFEs with new harvesting equipment (i.e., chainsaws and skidders) and made credit schemes available to emerging private entrepreneurs. 20. Forest Roads. Although logging has been going on for over 100 years in BH, only since 1945 have trucks been used on forest roads. Earlier, special logging railways and cable systems were used for log transport. About 2,000 km of such railways were in use at any one time. Both systems were gradually abolished due to high costs, and the last railways ceased to operate in 1970. At present the total length of forest roads is an estimated 11,000 km. The road density in high forests is about 10 m/ha, which is too low for efficient management of the forests and results in high logging costs and environmental harm due to long skidding distance. Once the existing forest roads network is rehabilitated, an increase in road density would be desirable. Before the war, forest roads were well constructed according to a high standard and seem to have been well maintained. Construction was undertaken either by the SFEs or by specialized contractors. Road maintenance was carried out by the SFEs or contracted out for a period of 3-6 years, depending on frequency of use. 21. The conditions of forest roads deteriorated dramatically during the war; many roads and bridges were damaged by heavy mi]iatary vehicles. Since the war, forest road rehabilitation has not resumed, which has become a key bottleneck to resuming normal forest management. The standards to which the forest roads are built demand that the roads must undergo regular maintenance to be usable for log transport. Lack of maintenance since before the war has caused heavy damage to the road surface, ditches and cross drainage, and to the bridges. About 3,400 km of forest roads in the Federation and 3,100 km in RS need urgent maintenance and repair work. Unless forest roads are repaired and maintained to allow access to other areas of forest, the areas which are now accessible will continue to be overexploited. In order to cope with the road rehabilitation needs, SFEs urgently need to be provided with basic equipment for road repair and maintenance. Wood Industry 22. BH has a long tradition in manufacturing mechanical wood products. The pre-war forest industry was based on substantial (i.e., about 3.5 million ni3 a year) and suitable wood raw material, advanced technology, high professional and labor skill, largely modem plant technology and a good market both domestically and abroad. Before the war, the furniture industry was one of the most important sectors, counting for more than 10 percent of the total industry production and generating a net export income of US$ 200 million. Main export markets were the Balkans (25-30%) and other neighboring countries such as Italy, France and Germany. The sector developed rapidly following World War II and in the mid 1980's a total of nearly 180 wood processing factories, of which 60 percent were in the Federation and 40 percent in RS, were operating for both primary (sawmilling) and secondary (furniture, joinery parquets, etc.) production (see Table 2 below).

Institutional Framework 24. Forestry Legislation. Before the war, the 1978 Forest Law - of which a brief account is given in Appendix 7 (Attachment 1) -- was in force in Bosnia. That Law is still in force in the Federation, but is ill adapted to the Federation's new organizational structure. A new Forest Law has been prepared for the Federation, to provide an adequate legal framework for sustainable management of forest resources in the new entity, but has not yet been approved. This is a major issue since essential legal provisions -- such as the organization of Forest Inspection Services to enforce the law, and the organization of forest management umts - are not in force. Approval of the draft new Forestry Law by the Government and subsequent submission to the Parliament of the Federation will be a condition of effectiveness of the project. As regards RS, a new Forest Law (02-764/94) has been in force since 1994 which provides an adequate legal framework for forest management in that entity. 25. Public Forestry Administration. The Ministry of Agriculture, Water Resources and Forestry (M4WF) and the MAinistry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Resources (MAFW) have overall responsibility for forestry in the Federation and in RS respectively. The Forestry Department within these Ministries is headed by a Vice-Minister who has a small technical staff including a Forest Inspection Service (FIS). In the Federation, 10 Cantons have been set up for regional administration as part of the Dayton Agreement. These Cantons have a similar administrative structure as the Federal administration, including a Minister in charge of a Cantonal MAWF. The Cantons are not fully operational yet. The Cantonal MAWFs are likely to have a small forestry department headed by a Vice-Minister, to handle forestry matters in the Canton. The exact responsibilities of these departments and their relation with other State entities in the forestry sector will be further clarified in the new Forest Law. 26. Before the war, the Forest Inspection Service (FIS) used to monitor and inspect forestry related activities regularly to ensure compliance with the Forest Law and relevant regulations. The FIS operated under the overall control of a State Forest Inspector and had an organizational network which extended to the Commune level; there were Commune Forest Inspectors (CFIs) in some 90 Communes. The CFIs
 Technical Annex Page 8 of 27 supervised the activities of the forest and industrial enterprises in their areas. This system collapsed during the war; it is being re-established progressively in the Federation and RS and is supposed to include one general inspector at the central level and field inspectorates (10 in the Federation and 16 in RS). Field inspectors in the Federation are likely to be established under the authority of the Cantonal administration. For the time being, FISs lack the basic equipment and funding they need to operate. 27. State Forest Enterprises. State owned forests were initially managed by socially owned State forest enterprises called Sumsko Privredno Preduzece (gPP). The SPPs typically managed both the forest industries and the surrounding forest areas which provided raw material to those industries. A reform program for SPPs was underway before the war. In most cases the SPPs were divided into separate industrial enterprises (sawmills, furniture, factories, etc.) and SFEs. In the case of the industrial enterprises, a process of privatization was started by increasing financial autonomy and offering shares to the workers. This process of privatization was interrupted by the war and there is still a majority share ownership of the State; however, it is expected to resume as soon as conditions permit. In the case of the SFEs, it was decided to keep them under State ownership, as is done in most forest rich countries. 28. The SFEs (45 Sumarstvos in the Federation, and 43 gumsko Gazdinstvos in RS) are presently the main unit managing State forests. They manage an average area of high forest of about 15,000 ha; however, some SFEs have lost a large part of their area of control due to changes in bouandaries resulting from the war and the Dayton agreement. SFEs used to operate as autonomous units, were largely financed by their own revenues and, in the past, made substantial contributions to the national budget. In the Bosniac part of the Federation the Sumarstvos are still fairly independent. They have to meet expenses from their own revenues and maintain independent accounting systems. In the Herzegovinian part of the Federation, the Sumarstvos are managed together as one entity. Incomes can be redistributed amongst the Sumarstvos as necessary and the accounting system is centralized. The level of autonomy and financial arrangements governing the gumarstvos has not yet been settled in anticipation of the new Forest Law. In RS, Sumsko Gazdinstvos were independent during the war; they are now being progressively integrated in Srpske Sume. In both the Federation and RS, SFEs have lost most of their operational capacity for adequate surveillance and management of their forests with the destruction or loss of basic equipment (e.g., vehicles, telecommunication) and facilities (e.g., nurseries). 29. Forest holding companies, called Bosanskoherzegovacke Sume (BH gume) in the Federation and Srpske Sume in RS, have recently been formed to be responsible for all state owned forests within each entity and to bring SFEs under more integrated management. BH Sume is not fully operational yet and its final status and relation to local authorities (cantons) and to the Sumarstvos are to be defined in the new Forest Law currently being drafted. Srpske Sume has a more advanced organization and is progressively becoming operational. 30. Staffing. The overall number of staff working in forest management is about half of what it was before the war. The situation is particularly bad in areas where most of the population has been displaced due to the war. Although there was significant overstaffing before the war, the present management capacity is only sufficient to resume part of the pre-war operational level. Adequate staffing levels are critical, particularly in positions dealing with management and control, in both SFEs and the Forest Inspection Services. The general situation is changing daily with the return of de-mobilized soldiers and refugees. 31. Forestry Research and Training. The Forestry Research Institute in Sarajevo was totally demolished during the war and its reconstruction will be costly and time consuming. SIPAD (a holding
 Technical Annex Page 9 of 27 company for forest industries) had a Planning and Research Department consisting of 2 units, one in Sarajevo and one in Banija Luka, whose main activity was to prepare forest management plans for the SFEs and for private forest owners on contract. These units became independent from Â§IPAD in 1990 and stopped functioning dunng the war; the facilities in Sarajevo were largely destroyed. The remains of these units and its present small staff have been reabsorbed into BH Sume and Srpske Sume. The unit in the latter is supposed to develop research activities in addition to FMPs. Forestry training was also totally disrupted during the war. Forestry curricula are being re-established in the faculties of forestry in the Universities of Sarajevo and Banja Luka. 32. The Private Sector. The private secjor plays a modest role in forest management, since private ownership is limited to about 19 percent of the forest area. Production and self consumption of firewood are the main objectives of the forestry activities carred out by private owners. The large number of private small landowners and the degraded structure of many private forests reduce the private sector's political importance. The involvement of private enterprises in felling, harvesting and transport of logs is still modest but has significantly increased since the end of the war. 33. Fiscal and Marketing Policies. Under the fiscal system in the pre-war period, the forestry sector was expected to generate sufficient revenues to replant and maintain the forest, provide improved facilities to workers and staff, and make a significant contribution to the national budget. Often SFEs were also expected to play a social function and employ more staff than was required. Under the Forestry Law, a local tax of 10 percent of sales revenue was levied on all SFEs. Revenues from this tax were administered by the communes and supposed to be used for replanting. SFEs typically also set aside another 10 percent of sales revenue to purchase new equipment as required; pay for preparation of forest management plans and various studies; and construct new houses and facilities for their workers. Most SFEs had substantial funds remaining even after making the above provisions. In some cases these net surpluses exceeded 20 percent of revenues. These funds were passed back to the State through a profit tax of 35 percent and as direct transfer. 34. During the war the forest industry collapsed and ceased to make any significant contribution to the national fiscal system. Most SFEs were unable to operate normally and took to selling standing trees to private contractors. Revenues generated from the sale of trees was used to pay workers and essential operating expenses. In some cases the SFEs could not even generate these funds and workers were not paid for many months. Their obligation under the Forest Law to set aside a share of sales revenue continues. The extent to which SFEs have managed to set aside these funds is unclear as many do not pay these taxes but claim to have replanted the forests themselves. However, given the limited sale of wood and consequent difficulties even with paying salaries, it is doubtful if they have been able to set aside the amounts required for replanting. 35, The pre-war fiscal system which relied on taxes and transfer of profit was appropriate for a situation where most harvesting was done by the SFEs. It is not suitable for a system where harvesting is increasingly being done by small private contractors. Over the long run it would be necessary to move to a system where the stumpage charge on standing trees is the main method of extracting rent from the forestry sector. The selling of standing trees, which is emerging gradually, is in principle the correct one, although the price paid may not be appropriate due to the depressed economic conditions and difficulties faced by the industry. A review of the fiscal and wood pricing systems is needed to assess how best the forestry sector could contribute to social development and tax collection. The project would fund such a review.

The selective felling management system, traditionally practiced in BH, warrants satisfactory conservation of the present level of forest biodiversity under the project. This system aims at keeping all age classes in forest stands. In such a system harvesting takes place at regular intervals (about every 10th year), and includes the felling of mature trees and a cross section in all age classes at a level which ensures that the same amount, quality and species distribution would be available at the following harvesting interval in perpetuity. Only limited clearfelling is allowed, mainly to improve degraded forest. As a result of this system, most of the forests in BH are naturally regenerated. This system is conducive to conservation of biodiversity, since the diversity of natural stands is maintained to the maximum extent possible during the whole production cycle. 75. Improved land-use planning would also enhance the broader value of the forest by permitting better multi-functional forest planning and use, categorizing forests into those with primarily sustainable production, watershed protection, ecological or recreational purposes; (c) Control of insect populations over 150,000 ha of highly infested forests would abate spreading of insect attacks over 350,000 ha of coniferous high forests and prevent a significant destruction of the standing stock, which would in turn prevent the loss in annual marketable production of at least 100,000 rn3 of logs. Reforestation in 500 ha of land susceptible to erosion would protect human infrastructure from the risk of landslide. Technical and logistical support to development of the protected areas system would improve management and landuse planning and enhance the ecological and environmental value of these sensitive areas; (d) The equipment for rehabilitation of forest roads funded under the project would permit rehabilitation of about 4,000 kms of forest roads in high forests over an estimated 10 years. This would benefit approximately 40,000 ha of high forest annually, making an estimated additional annual amount of 400,000 rn3 of marketable wood in mature stands eventually available for harvesting. This would also lower the cost of harvesting wood by reducing the required distance for "skidding" wood from the harvest site to the roadside. The component also has two types of environmental benefits. First, by reducing the skidding distance it reduces soil disturbance and erosion in areas which are harvested. It also reduces damage to remaining stands and permits more rapid regeneration. Second, by rehabilitating roads it permits geographically more balanced harvesting, avoiding overharvesting at the (previously) limited accessible sites; (e) The provision of transport equipment would permit extraction of sanitary fellings of about 120,000 rn3 per year, increasing also the growth rate and harvest value of the remaining healthy growing stock. The nursery equipment would permit an increase in seedling production of about 6 million seedlings per year. The telecommunications equipment and vehicles would improve overall forest management by permitting improved monitoring and earlier detection of illegal harvesting and fires. It would also help ensure overall law enforcement and implementation of management plans. Economic Justification 98. Most of the benefits of the project are environmental and could not be quantified and evaluated against project costs. A contingency evaluation method would be an appropriate way of evaluating these environmental benefits but, given the present situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, concepts such as "willingness to pay" and "existence value" cannot be meaningfully estimated. In addition, a comprehensive analysis of the commercial benefits derived from project support was not possible mainly because: (i) the project was prepared under an emergency approach which did not allow for a comprehensive collection of relevant data; and (ii) recent and reliable data on prices and marketing are scarce in a post-war country.

The analysis deals with these benefits only and does not take into account other commercial benefits (e.g., fuelwood, non-wood forest products); the analysis is based on very conservative assumptions and considers a 10-year period only -- whereas a 50-year period is normally considered for investment in forests -- since the project is by nature a reconstruction project from which benefits are mostly expected in the short or medium terms. The activities analyzed are: (i) forest protection from insect attacks; (ii) forest roads maintenance and repair; (iii) provision of wood transport equipment; and (iv) nursery rehabilitation. This equipment would be used for rehabilitating forest roads damaged due to the war situation, either directly by heavy wear or due to neglected maintenance. Note that the equipment is presumed to be used for repair and maintenance, and not for construction of new roads. 2. Road Graders. The specification of the road graders would be: engine, diesel with direct injection and an effect of 160 - 180 kW; rear axle with driven boogie; grading device according to international standard with width of 12 feet; front mounted dozer blade; safety cab according to OECD standards. 3. Specialized Tractors. The project would fund specialized tractors with front loader and rear mounted excavator, with the following specifications: engine, diesel with direct injection with an effect of 80 - 90 kW (105 - 120 hp); * front mounted hook-on bucket, with a capacity of 1.5 - 3.0 me (choice of bucket); * rear mounted excavator unit with a maximum reach of at least 6 m and a digging depth of at least 4 m, buckeit capacity 100-400 litre (choice of bucket); * safety cab according to OECD standards. Road Transport Equipment 4. The road transport equipment will be used for transporting logs from sanitary fellings, from the landings at road side in the forest to the end user (saw mills, pulp mills, etc). The trucks will be equipped with a hydraulic loading crane which can load both the truck itself and a trailer coupled to the truck. The total length of truck and trailer shall not to exceed 18.35 m, which is the standard length in Europe. 5. Trucks with Cranes. The specifications of the trucks with crane would be: engine/diesel with direct injection, fulfilling international standards for low exhaust emissions, with am effect of 210 - 240 kW (280 - 320 hp); payload of minimum 10 tons of logs; rear axle with boogie; superstructure with at least two bunks and stake;
 APPENDIX 4 Page 2 of 3 * rear mounted hydraulic loading crane with rotator and grapple dimensioned to load a two-axle trailer; * front wall to protect the cab; * distance between front wall and crane dimensioned for at least 6 m logs; * towing hook including electric and brake connections. 6. Trailers. The specifications of the two axle log trailers would be: * steel chassis with four pairs of bunks with stakes enabling transport of shorter logs in two sections; * tires 12 x 20 mounted on steel rims; * equipped with rapid couplers for the electric and hydraulic brake systems of the trailer. Other Forestry Equipment 7. Agriculture Tractors and Trailers. These tractors will be standard agricultural tractors to be used in a multi-purpose way such as: (i) forest nursery work with the possibility to be equipped with different implements (e.g., cultivator, plough, disc harrow); (ii) transport work equipped with a 5- tons two-axle trailer (e.g., transport of gravel for road repair work); and (iii) off road transport (skidding) of logs as a complement or substitute to articulated skidders. 8. The specifications of the multi-purpose tractors would be the following: * engine, diesel with direct injection with an effect of 60 - 70 kW (80 - 95 hp); * four wheel drive; * articulated steering; * rear power take off (PTO); * three-point hitch; * front and rear towing hook with electric and brake connections; * hydraulic tipping attachment with rapid couplers for trailer and other agricultural implements; * safety cab according to OECD standards. 9. The specifications of the single axle trailer with hydraulic rear tipping would be the following: * capacity 4-5 ton; * platform dimensions about 350x180 cm; * complete with hydraulic hoses, and rapid couplers to the tractor hydraulic and braking systems. 10. Buses. The project would fund buses -- for the transport of forestry personnel to and from their work sites in the forest and elsewhere -- with the following specifications: * engine, diesel with direct injection with an effect of about 55 - 65 kW (75 - 85 hp); * nine seats including driver.

Forestry Management: Production forestry in the FBiH has a long history, dating back to around 1878, when the Austrian-Hungarian Monarchy came to control the region. Currently the dominant system is "selective felling" which has been practised in RBiH since 1968. In contrast to the more common system of forest management with aims at creating even aged forests, this system aims at creating stands containing trees in all age classes. Harvesting take place at regular intervals (about every 10th year), and includes the felling of mature, dead and damaged trees and a cross section in all age classes at a level which ensures that the same amount, quality and species distribution would be available at the following harvesting interval. Clearfelling is not allowed, unless it is required to improve degraded forest. The majority of the forests are naturally regenerated in BiH. Environmental Legislation in the pre-war period: In the former Yugoslavia, the constituent Republics had a high degree of autonomy to manage many of their internal affairs, leaving the federal government a very limited set of powers. In the environmental area the federal government had jurisdiction only in international or inter-Republic matters. Most Republics developed some form of environmental administration and regulations and at one time there were some 400 laws and 1,000 regulations covering environmental protection (Pravdic, 1993). The republics were given jurisdiction over both federal and republican environmental enforcement organs (Article 286 of the former Yugoslavia Constitution). This system also gave considerable scope to the communes for the protection of the local environment through the passing of regulations and the planning and implementation of environmental control systems. 23. Budgetary Regulations: Local government units were required by law to be self- supporting. All funds for local social welfare programmes and public services had to be raised locally. Many local services were mandatory, and local government and industry had substantial portions of their budget allocated to these mandatory activities. Environmental protection was not a mandated public service. As a consequence, environmental programmes could not depend on a public source of permanent funding and there was little incentive to undertake costly environmental improvements. An example, resulting from this system, is the high level of pollution in the river Bosna, where significant amounts of domestic solid waste and industrial effluents are discharged. 24. The inspectors, who were all qualified forest engineers, had the authority to stop illegal operations in the forests and to apply fines in cases of violations.

In the FMP the allowable cutting volumes are summarized and presented for: treatment class; management unit; and commune. 28. The AC is calculated in different ways depending on the specific conditions of each TC. For TCs defined as "High Quality" High Forests, the volume of selected trees (V,) is calculated and compared with the yield (Y) for the same TC. The AC is then calculated as AC= (V1 + Y)/2. 29. When the present volume of a TC (V,) differs substantially from the standard volume (V2), and it is judged that the volume could not be reached within the plan period, the AC is calculated as follows: AC= Y + (V,- V2)/S where S is the number of plan periods during which the standard volume is planned be reached, normally 2 or 3 periods. 30. The project would have environmental benefits and would permit increased and sustained production of wood; these benefits are discussed below: (a) Technical support to analysis of policy changes would examine the implications of institutional reforns and changes in marketing, pricing and trade, which would result in improved management of forest resources and, eventually, in increased revenues to the state; (b) The technical support to improved forest management planning would permit more timely harvesting and maintenance of trees, improving the value of the product. Improved land-use planning would also enhance the broader value of the forest by permitting better multi-functional forest planning and use, categorizing forests into those with primarily sustainable production, watershed protection, ecological or recreational purposes; (c) Control of insect populations over 150,000 ha of highly infested forests would abate spreading of insect attacks over 350,000 ha of coniferous high forests and prevent a significant destruction of the standing stock, which would in turn prevent the loss in annual marketable production of at least 100,000 m3 of logs. Reforestation in 500 ha of land susceptible to erosion would protect human infrastructure from the risk of landslide. Technical and logistical support to development of the protected areas system would improve management and landuse planning and enhance the ecological and environmental value of these sensitive areas; (d) The equipment for rehabilitation of forest roads funded under the project would permit rehabilitation of about 4,000 kms of forest roads in high forests over an estimated 10 years. This would benefit approximately 40,000 ha of high forest annually, making an estimated additional annual amount of 400,000 m3 of marketable wood in mature stands eventually available for harvesting. This would also lower the cost of harvesting wood by reducing the required distance for "skidding" wood from the harvest site to the roadside. The component also has two types of environmental benefits. First, by reducing the skidding distance it reduces soil disturbance and erosion in areas which are harvested. It also reduces damage to remaining stands and permits more rapid regeneration. Second, by rehabilitating roads it permits geographically more balanced harvesting, avoiding overharvesting at the (previously) limited accessible sites; (e) The provision of transport equipment would permit extraction of sanitary fellings of about 100,000 m3 per year, increasing also the growth rate and harvest value of the remaining healthy growing stock. The nursery equipment would permit an increase in seedling production of about 6 million seedlings per year. The telecommunications equipment and vehicles would improve overall forest management by permitting improved

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Forestry Project for Bosnia-Herzegovina is to resume sustainable management and protection of Bosnian forest resources in order to 1) ensure the sustainability of the rapid recovery of the wood harvesting and wood processing sectors; and 2) control the potential environment impact of this recovery. The project funds the following four components: 1) Support to Forest Management includes support for a) policy changes, through studies on the institutional aspects and fiscal and marketing aspects of the forestry sector; b) forest management planning; and c) re-establishing forest inspection services to resume and secure adequate enforcement of forestry legislation. 2) Forest Protection and Rehabilitation include a comprehensive insect control program; reforestation; and rehabilitation of the national park and development of new protected areas, including technical assistance and training. 3) Rehabilitation of the State Forest Enterprise's Operational Capacity, which provides equipment for repairing and maintaining existing forest roads damaged during the war; and for resuming normal surveillance and protection of forests, carrying out forest regeneration and other silvicultural works, and organizing and controlling sustainable forest harvesting. 4) Project Management and Monitoring funds incremental staff to implement procurement, disbursement, auditing, and reporting procedures as well as technical assistance.
